meta_data.title: I'm Not Cracking a Bunch of Impalement Jokes This Time Around, That's Cheap Humor and It Has No Place on the Internet
meta_data.subtitle: ESTHER 5:9-14 Thanks to everyone who supports TMBH at  You're the reason we can all do this together!  Opening song, "" from the album, "" by

transcription_data.text: When I was a kid there was a comedian he had a show it came on after the news his name was David Letterman used to be a weatherman and he was great he was just funny his delivery worked it was quirky and off beat and he did this great job he'd introduce a running joke you kind of find the first thing that would work for the audience and then if things went awry with a guest or whatever you come right back to it and he had little bits it was kind of a variety show that made fun of the genre of variety show that at this point it existed for decades already and one of the bits that he would do is the top ten list he would write up these these sarcastic top ten lists of things I thought they were random and funny and hilarious as a kid when I was allowed to stay up after the news and catch the first segment or two of Letterman and eventually I got a book that had the best of David Letterman's top ten lists and one of them was something like top ten rejected after dinner mint names I might be making stuff up it was something like that because one of them was disembowel mint and I thought that was very funny is a sixth or seventh grade boy and another one was impale mint and so I went right off to school with that joke in my hip pocket and I tried it on a bunch of people like girls I wanted to impress and they did not laugh at all they just couldn't see the genius of the humor all I can think is that Letterman's delivery was a little bit stronger eventually I did get talked to by my teacher and I was told to refrain from jokes where anybody got disemboweled or impaled and in retrospect seems reasonable on their part but also still kind of funny still the real lesson here is there's no joke in about things like that so you can look forward to an episode here where we speculate about what the exact deal was with Haman's gallows that does not have the bunch of impalement jokes which aren't even funny anyway so I'm gonna try to avoid those here's the thing couple days ago we were talking about these gallows that Haman decides to build at the end of chapter five at the suggestion of his wife and his buddies and these gallows they're huge I mean they're just much taller than gallows would need to be and I was riffing a little bit about how you really don't need 75 feet worth of slack to do a hanging but generally what we picture when we hear the word gallows is like in the old west right like if the stage just got robbed by Limpity Jim or the snarkleberry kid now we rounded him up with the posse and now we're gonna put him on a platform in front of town and then the sheriff the local law man we're gonna do a frontier justice here we'll let the floor drop out and then they'll hang and I understand that's pretty dark but I mean come on the bible is the one who brought us to this point in the conversation because it's it's the one who started talking about public torture and execution methods here at the end of chapter five and well I think it's actually quite interesting and a completely valid point of conversation given what we're doing working through the book of Esther one little bit at a time to consider how the original audience would have viewed this threat like the original witnesses I mean what are they gonna think when a 75 foot gallows go up what would they even been looking at what would a 75 foot gallows look like at this point in Persia what would the original audience the first people to read the book think when they heard about this what image with this conjure to mind what meaning would this send regarding the transgressions and now the fate of whoever those gallows were intended for but here's the deal even though we're kind of joking around about something more in the style of an old west high noon posse Rob the stage coach hanging the other day when we talk about a gallows in the ancient world we're usually talking about a poll on which somebody would be impaled as I mean just speculate in here there's all kinds of primary source original evidence to say this was one of the main means of people in authority killing their political enemies or rebels to make a point what is that point well it's don't rebel against me or I'll do horrible things to you including desecrating your corpse I'm not just speculating about this we got all kinds of documentation from the ancient world that this was indeed their preferred method of execution situations like this I don't want to be gross but I want to describe to you a little bit about what this looks like in his nicer terms as possible so that we can picture what Haman had in mind when he had these huge gallows built the neo Assyrians were really into impalement the Assyrians were horrible it was the worst there the enemies of really both the northern and the southern kingdom but the northern kingdom meets their fate at the hands of the Assyrians in 732 and the Assyrians took the extra time to carve reliefs showing memorializing their impalement of defeated enemies and rebels and I'm looking at one of these reliefs here I've seen this one in person but it shows two Assyrian soldiers with something that looks like a lance from like jousting in the middle ages and they have impaled someone upon it and they've clearly walked it vertical together and then stuck it in a hole in the ground there's another one over here that shows like a rock or concrete base that holds the gallows in place to stabilize it because the weight of the victim obviously is going to affect things now generally speaking I think of the Persians who come along two empires after Assyria as being friendlier I think everybody would agree it was a better time under Persia than under Assyria but even so the Persians were really really into impaling as well Darius was into impaling Xerxes was into impaling Herodotus gives us accounts of Darius impaling people in fact Darius was so proud of his impaling that in that famous Behiston inscription that stone inscription that he put up for the whole world to see forever he talks about and even displays how he impaled rebels and people who promulgated the lie about false succession that came after the era of Cyrus after the conquest of Babylon or putting down a rebellion in Babylon maybe it was Darius boasts about impaling 3000 Babylonians to make a point of that and further we know that Darius Xerxes dad the guy from whom Xerxes learned how it's good and proper to rule and what you got to do when people misbehave. Darius talked about his impaling practices and Ezra 6 when he found out that King Cyrus had indeed authorized the Jews to go back and rebuild the temple and so forth and then interlopers had come and disrupted the process while Darius makes an even bigger even bolder proclamation about what will happen if anybody resists this rebuilding effort happening on the part of the Jews he says in verse 11 of Ezra 6. Furthermore I Darius decreed that if anyone changes this edict the beam is to be pulled from his house and he is to be lifted up and impaled on it and for this crime his house is to be made a pile of rubble. May God who has caused his name to dwell there overthrow any king or people who lifts a hand to change this decree or to destroy the temple in Jerusalem so that sounds like Darius I mean that sounds like the language that you and I have been over that he reals off in the bahistan inscription that we've talked so much about that that impulse to say whatever is decreed before by one of the kings should be held up by the successors because he felt that his reign and his claim to power was a little bit fragile and so he tried to prop it up for generations to come making these kind of bold proclamations demonstrating his continuity looking backwards and hopefully in his mind looking forward so we get that bit of continuity with the character of Darius but then we also get the idea that clearly he thinks impaling is a threat that everybody will understand he imagines that impaling crosses linguistic and cultural boundaries I mean pretty much everybody gets it the visual cues are all right there you wouldn't want that to happen to you so don't do the things that the people up there on that stake must have done what makes the most sense for me here in ester five is that this gallows would be the most common approach to executing people the most well-documented approach to executing people particularly rebels particular people you want to make an example of in the ancient world and in the Persian empire so I don't think we're talking about an old westy hanging frontier justice kind of thing I think we're talking about it the sort of thing where what Haman wants to do is take a gigantic pole run Mordecai partway through with that gigantic pole and then use a series of pulleys and levers to crank that thing back up higher than the city walls of sousa even to show people both inside the city and outside the city walls this is what happens when you disrespect Haman it's a horrifying fate and a horrifying image and I think if we're honest about what this practice looked like in the ancient world we better understand how this would have struck the original audience and we better understand the stakes that come with that time crunch that we were talking about yesterday and all the more so we find ourselves turning the page toward ester chapter six knowing that ester is not positioned to solve this this is going to happen before the next time she has access to Haman or the king what needs to happen is some help from some outside source like Mordecai himself had suggested would have to come along what will it be next time around we'll look into that and find out we got a bunch of people signed up for the 1000 episode party that we got coming up here in whatever it is two and a half weeks three weeks and I'm super excited about that a bunch of you're coming to my hometown of Rapid City South Dakota and our event is taking shape in terms of details as we're getting a sense of attendance who else going to be here both for the monday the 25th when we do our evening 1000 episode party and for the following day on Tuesday when we do our much smaller super adorable mini conference for pastors that we're going to have everyone who is signed up we've got you on a list we got the email addresses and everything and we will be in communication with you I would guess early part of next week as we finalize those details it's going to be so much fun I'm so grateful for everybody who's up for making that trip I'm also grateful to the rest of you for listening as well and in your brain you can just feel celebratory things during that time and I think it'll mostly count and final note here I gotta say that I think this episode was a huge win I set out from the beginning not to repeat the mistakes of my youth going around cracking ill-advised jokes about impalement and here we are we've made it to the end with no dumb impalement jokes whatsoever and I think that's a gigantic win all right that's plenty I'm Matt this is the 10 minute Bible hour podcast let's do this again soon you

segments.text: When I was a kid there was a comedian he had a show it came on after the news his name
was David Letterman used to be a weatherman and he was great he was just funny his delivery
worked it was quirky and off beat and he did this great job he'd introduce a running joke
you kind of find the first thing that would work for the audience and then if things went
awry with a guest or whatever you come right back to it and he had little bits it was kind
of a variety show that made fun of the genre of variety show that at this point it existed
for decades already and one of the bits that he would do is the top ten list he would write
up these these sarcastic top ten lists of things I thought they were random and funny
and hilarious as a kid when I was allowed to stay up after the news and catch the first
segment or two of Letterman and eventually I got a book that had the best of David Letterman's
top ten lists and one of them was something like top ten rejected after dinner mint names
I might be making stuff up it was something like that because one of them was disembowel
mint and I thought that was very funny is a sixth or seventh grade boy and another one
was impale mint and so I went right off to school with that joke in my hip pocket and
I tried it on a bunch of people like girls I wanted to impress and they did not laugh
at all they just couldn't see the genius of the humor all I can think is that Letterman's
delivery was a little bit stronger eventually I did get talked to by my teacher and I was
told to refrain from jokes where anybody got disemboweled or impaled and in retrospect
seems reasonable on their part but also still kind of funny still the real lesson here is
there's no joke in about things like that so you can look forward to an episode here
where we speculate about what the exact deal was with Haman's gallows that does not have
the bunch of impalement jokes which aren't even funny anyway so I'm gonna try to avoid
those here's the thing couple days ago we were talking about these gallows that Haman decides
to build at the end of chapter five at the suggestion of his wife and his buddies and
these gallows they're huge I mean they're just much taller than gallows would need to
be and I was riffing a little bit about how you really don't need 75 feet worth of slack
to do a hanging but generally what we picture when we hear the word gallows is like in the
old west right like if the stage just got robbed by Limpity Jim or the snarkleberry
kid now we rounded him up with the posse and now we're gonna put him on a platform in
front of town and then the sheriff the local law man we're gonna do a frontier justice
here we'll let the floor drop out and then they'll hang and I understand that's pretty
dark but I mean come on the bible is the one who brought us to this point in the conversation
because it's it's the one who started talking about public torture and execution methods
here at the end of chapter five and well I think it's actually quite interesting and
a completely valid point of conversation given what we're doing working through the
book of Esther one little bit at a time to consider how the original audience would have
viewed this threat like the original witnesses I mean what are they gonna think when a 75
foot gallows go up what would they even been looking at what would a 75 foot gallows look
like at this point in Persia what would the original audience the first people to read
the book think when they heard about this what image with this conjure to mind what
meaning would this send regarding the transgressions and now the fate of whoever those gallows
were intended for but here's the deal even though we're kind of joking around about something
more in the style of an old west high noon posse Rob the stage coach hanging the other
day when we talk about a gallows in the ancient world we're usually talking about a poll on
which somebody would be impaled as I mean just speculate in here there's all kinds of
primary source original evidence to say this was one of the main means of people in authority
killing their political enemies or rebels to make a point what is that point well it's
don't rebel against me or I'll do horrible things to you including desecrating your corpse
I'm not just speculating about this we got all kinds of documentation from the ancient
world that this was indeed their preferred method of execution situations like this I
don't want to be gross but I want to describe to you a little bit about what this looks
like in his nicer terms as possible so that we can picture what Haman had in mind when
he had these huge gallows built the neo Assyrians were really into impalement the Assyrians were
horrible it was the worst there the enemies of really both the northern and the southern
kingdom but the northern kingdom meets their fate at the hands of the Assyrians in 732 and
the Assyrians took the extra time to carve reliefs showing memorializing their impalement of defeated
enemies and rebels and I'm looking at one of these reliefs here I've seen this one in person
but it shows two Assyrian soldiers with something that looks like a lance from like jousting in
the middle ages and they have impaled someone upon it and they've clearly walked it vertical
together and then stuck it in a hole in the ground there's another one over here that shows like
a rock or concrete base that holds the gallows in place to stabilize it because the weight of
the victim obviously is going to affect things now generally speaking I think of the Persians who
come along two empires after Assyria as being friendlier I think everybody would agree it was
a better time under Persia than under Assyria but even so the Persians were really really into
impaling as well Darius was into impaling Xerxes was into impaling Herodotus gives us accounts
of Darius impaling people in fact Darius was so proud of his impaling that in that famous
Behiston inscription that stone inscription that he put up for the whole world to see forever
he talks about and even displays how he impaled rebels and people who promulgated the lie about
false succession that came after the era of Cyrus after the conquest of Babylon or putting down a
rebellion in Babylon maybe it was Darius boasts about impaling 3000 Babylonians to make a point
of that and further we know that Darius Xerxes dad the guy from whom Xerxes learned how it's
good and proper to rule and what you got to do when people misbehave. Darius talked about his
impaling practices and Ezra 6 when he found out that King Cyrus had indeed authorized the Jews to
go back and rebuild the temple and so forth and then interlopers had come and disrupted the process
while Darius makes an even bigger even bolder proclamation about what will happen if anybody
resists this rebuilding effort happening on the part of the Jews he says in verse 11 of Ezra
6. Furthermore I Darius decreed that if anyone changes this edict the beam is to be pulled from
his house and he is to be lifted up and impaled on it and for this crime his house is to be made a
pile of rubble. May God who has caused his name to dwell there overthrow any king or people who
lifts a hand to change this decree or to destroy the temple in Jerusalem so that sounds like Darius
I mean that sounds like the language that you and I have been over that he reals off in the
bahistan inscription that we've talked so much about that that impulse to say whatever is
decreed before by one of the kings should be held up by the successors because he felt that his
reign and his claim to power was a little bit fragile and so he tried to prop it up for generations
to come making these kind of bold proclamations demonstrating his continuity looking backwards
and hopefully in his mind looking forward so we get that bit of continuity with the character
of Darius but then we also get the idea that clearly he thinks impaling is a threat that
everybody will understand he imagines that impaling crosses linguistic and cultural boundaries I mean
pretty much everybody gets it the visual cues are all right there you wouldn't want that to happen
to you so don't do the things that the people up there on that stake must have done what makes
the most sense for me here in ester five is that this gallows would be the most common approach
to executing people the most well-documented approach to executing people particularly rebels
particular people you want to make an example of in the ancient world and in the Persian empire
so I don't think we're talking about an old westy hanging frontier justice kind of thing I think
we're talking about it the sort of thing where what Haman wants to do is take a gigantic pole
run Mordecai partway through with that gigantic pole and then use a series of pulleys and levers
to crank that thing back up higher than the city walls of sousa even to show people both inside the
city and outside the city walls this is what happens when you disrespect Haman it's a horrifying
fate and a horrifying image and I think if we're honest about what this practice looked like
in the ancient world we better understand how this would have struck the original audience and
we better understand the stakes that come with that time crunch that we were talking about
yesterday and all the more so we find ourselves turning the page toward ester chapter six knowing
that ester is not positioned to solve this this is going to happen before the next time she has
access to Haman or the king what needs to happen is some help from some outside source like Mordecai
himself had suggested would have to come along what will it be next time around we'll look into
that and find out we got a bunch of people signed up for the 1000 episode party that we got coming
up here in whatever it is two and a half weeks three weeks and I'm super excited about that a
bunch of you're coming to my hometown of Rapid City South Dakota and our event is taking shape
in terms of details as we're getting a sense of attendance who else going to be here both for
the monday the 25th when we do our evening 1000 episode party and for the following day on
Tuesday when we do our much smaller super adorable mini conference for pastors that we're going to
have everyone who is signed up we've got you on a list we got the email addresses and everything
and we will be in communication with you I would guess early part of next week as we finalize those
details it's going to be so much fun I'm so grateful for everybody who's up for making that trip I'm
also grateful to the rest of you for listening as well and in your brain you can just feel celebratory
things during that time and I think it'll mostly count and final note here I gotta say that I think
this episode was a huge win I set out from the beginning not to repeat the mistakes of my youth
going around cracking ill-advised jokes about impalement and here we are we've made it to the end
with no dumb impalement jokes whatsoever and I think that's a gigantic win all right that's
plenty I'm Matt this is the 10 minute Bible hour podcast let's do this again soon
you
